subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: Your point is a good one. A reexamination of the QM was what led me to drop the alternate #8 from QS-SAMPA. There are still 6 unassigned capital letters,
messageBody:
Your point is a good one. A reexamination of the QM was what led me to
drop the 'alternate' #8 from QS-SAMPA. There are still 6 unassigned
capital letters, which can be used for alternate glyphs and ligatures.
Perhaps they should be standardized as well, but let's not get ahead
of ourselves just yet.

Of course people should remap their own keyboards however they like,
no matter what standard we choose. (I've used the Dvorak layout for 7
years, for example.)

What I really want is a standard way to represent QS in ASCII that is
based on a linguistic standard and is as readable as possible. I find
the mapping used by currently available fonts lacking in several
respects.

I recently joined the shawalphabet group to see what they're up
to--immediately I received a message with the "standard font for
Shavian writing in this group", followed by messages with shavian
written in ASCII. That's exactly what I want for QS. (Digging further,
I found files with different keyboard layouts, so I guess their
standard does not please everyone in the group.)

I plan to use the QS-SAMPA mapping for the font I'm developing.

Ted


On Nov 29, 2007 11:31 AM, Anthony Grahn <othermale@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
>
> <freeman@...> wrote:
> >
> > PS. Someone, perhaps Anthony, will no doubt point out that I've
> > included both Junior QS and alternative letters that are properly
> > Senior QS letters. I would only say that we have room for them, so
> > let's go ahead and assign them. Likewise, if people want to add the
> > so-called "alternative letters" for #8 and #22, we have room for them
> > as well and I'm open to any suggestions.
> >
>
> I do not mean to discourage anything. Quite to the contrary, I'd love
> to see a wider range of the QS glyphs drawn and discussed. I just
> wanted to point out that one shouldn't be too prejudiced by what
> happens to be in already existing fonts when one is trying to figure
> out the glyphs necessary to represent QS.
>
> You may have already considered this but one option would be to create
> keyboard layouts that captures each person's particular preferences
> and mapping those to the Unicode PUA points we've been using.
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
>
>
> <freeman@...> wrote:
> >
> > I would like to propose that we adopt a single-character plain text
> > (ASCII) representation for the Read Alphabet, called QS-SAMPA. The
> > name reflects its origin as an adaptation of the X-SAMPA phonetic
> > alphabet (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-SAMPA). At the moment, we are
> > using heterogeneous notations, sometimes using names from the
> > Quickscript Manual, sometimes using letter numbers, and sometimes
> > using the revised names proposed by Jon Zuck. This is inconvenient.
> >
> > Also, the fonts that we currently have do not use identical
> > key-mappings. For example, 'W' represents #20 in the junior font and
> > the ligature #26+36 in the jerome and Thoth fonts. (All three fonts
> > map the backquote character to #20.) The present font-mappings are not
> > based on a current linguistic standard, as far as I can tell, and do
> > not really treat letters #20 and #41-44 as full members in the
> > alphabet. (For the numbering of #41-44, I have followed the example of
> > the document "qs manual modern (beta).pdf" under Files->Resources.)
> > Even if one does not choose to use these letters oneself, there is no
> > good reason to deprecate them or give them strange key assignments.
> >
> > QS-SAMPA uses lower and upper case Latin letters for all QS letters,
> > including the "4 alternative letter-symbols" and the two letters
> > introduced for use in "Scottish, Welsh, and Irish place names." It
> > also includes a standard for the name-dot and angled brackets.
> > Altogether, this list requires 46 letters and three punctuation marks.
> >
> > QS-SAMPA uses the backquote character for the name-dot because it
> > visually suggests the dot and is easy to type. Also, the backquote
> > itself is rarely needed. Assigning angled-brackets to '(' and ')'
> > seems like the obvious choice.
> >
> > QS-SAMPA would allow us to exchange written Quickscript as plain-text
> > in email. If supported by a Quickscript font, we would only have to
> > copy and paste the text into a word processor and change the font in
> > order to read it. I expect we would soon learn to read QS-SAMPA
> > directly as well.
> >
> > Adding parentheses to a famous quote, we would write:
> > The rain (in Spain) falls mainly on the plain.
> >
> > In QS-SAMPA this would be:
> > T ren (In `spen) fAlz menli An T plen.
> >
> > (Or at least, a West Coast American would write it that way.)
> >
> > The basis for the QS-SAMPA proposal is the adaptation of X-SAMPA to QS
> > recently suggested by John Cowen:
> > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/1538
> >
> > I've added a spreadsheet and pdf file related to this proposal to the
> > group website, under Files->QS-SAMPA. The spreadsheet, qs_sampa.pdf
> > (which comes from qs_sampa.xls) contains columns with QS numbers, QM
> > names, revised names, the present keyboard assignments used in the
> > Thoth and jerome fonts, and QS-SAMPA. The file qs_sampa_array.pdf (and
> > source file qs_sampa_array.rtf) is arranged similarly to chart in the
> > Quickscript Manual, using the Thoth and jerome fonts.
> >
> > For those of you who are accustomed to typing with the present
> > keyboard assignments, I hope the benefit of having a simple standard
> > would make it worth the effort of having to retrain yourselves.
> >
> > Let me know what you think. Thanks.
> >
> > Ted
> >
> > PS. Someone, perhaps Anthony, will no doubt point out that I've
> > included both Junior QS and alternative letters that are properly
> > Senior QS letters. I would only say that we have room for them, so
> > let's go ahead and assign them. Likewise, if people want to add the
> > so-called "alternative letters" for #8 and #22, we have room for them
> > as well and I'm open to any suggestions. Everything is on the table at
> > the moment, but it's high time we adopt a good standard.
> >
>
>
>
